issues.title: Is this plugin support mesos 1.4.1 and jenkins 2.89.2 ?
Jenkins can only launch slaves when talking to current mesos master
issues.body:
I have redundant mesos masters that elect through ZooKeeper, as is custom.  Other applications like marathon seem to be able to handle finding the master on their own, but Jenkins seems to only need to be connected to a single master, but has to be connected to the elected master.  So if this master moves due to maintenance or whatever, then Jenkins loses connectivity and cannot launch any slaves.

Has anyone else seen this behaviour?  We're running 1.2 here.  If there is something grossly missing or if I have the ability to enumerate all my masters and it can do the right thing from there, please let me know.  Otherwise, this seems like a bug.

Thanks much!

issues.title: When using 'Docker Image Can Be Customized', plugin ignores mesos offer selection attributes
issues.body: When a mesos cloud has multiple nodes and some nodes ares setup with specific mesos offer selection attributes, the agents that are created by mesos no longer are restricted to just those nodes in the defined selection attributes when a docker image is provided in a job using the 'Docker Image Can Be Customized'

issues.title: Using Mesos pods for enhancing the capabilities of the Mesos plugin
issues.body:
By using Mesos pods, it should be possible to implement new capabilities for the Mesos plugin like being able to use any Docker image as slave template and having the possibility to add side-containers to a build.

For using any Docker image as slave template, a pod with a Jenkins slave template linked to a build container should be created. The Jenkins slave manage the communication with the master and the build container is used for building using an ephemeral volume.

For side-containers we can consider to use the network capability for being able to access to the side container from `localhost`.

These kind of features are already available in [Jenkins Docker Slaves plugin](https://plugins.jenkins.io/docker-slaves) but without the ability to use an orchestrator like Mesos for running the containers.

issues.title: Spin up second slave with same label takes minutes
issues.body:
I am struggling with a performance issue when I have configured a multijob pipeline.

The pipeline job and a subjob are using the same Docker image as slave. Performance wise it's desired to spin up two containers (one for the pipeline job and one for the subjob). What happened is that when the pipeline job is running, that Jenkins / Mesos plugin waits for up to 4 minutes before deciding to spin up the second container. Jenkins tries to reuse the container that is already running. While it only has 1 executor and all the jobs are configured with "Mesos Single-Use Slave".

It looks like that there is a timeout anywhere that will wait for a couple of minutes before deciding to spin up an extra container. 

Is there a way to set the timeout for this or can we solve the issue in a different way?

issues.title: Node is offline when Mesos is placed at the remote machine

```
./mesos-master --registry=in_memory --ip=192.168.3.35 # or 127.0.0.1
./mesos-slave --work_dir=/Users/user/mesos_slave_workdir --master=192.168.3.35:5050 # or 127.0.0.1
```

issues.title: Entrypoint in Dockerfile will be automatically overridden by "/bin/sh -c"
issues.body:
Descriptions:
_Entrypoint in Dockerfile will be automatically be overridden  by Java slave process, but CMD in Dockerfile will not be overridden.  I think this problem will block the users who want to adopt this plugin as no way to identify which executable should be run when a container is started from our images, and I tried to use **Use custom docker command shell** in Mesos Cloud section to work around it, but still fails, a defect has been tracking it for also year: https://github.com/jenkinsci/mesos-plugin/issues/157_

**Entrypoint**: /bin/bash --login -- /entrypoint.sh
**Java Slave process**: /bin/sh -c 'java -DHUDSON_HOME=jenkins -server -Xmx640m -Xms16m -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC -Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true -jar ${MESOS_SANDBOX-.}/slave.jar -noReconnect -secret ... mesos-jenkins-do/slave-agent.jnlp

Expected (Shown by **COMMAND** via **docker ps** command):
"/bin/bash --login -- /entrypoint.sh /bin/sh -c 'java -DHUDSON_HOME=jenkins -server -Xmx640m -Xms16m -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC -Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true -jar ${MESOS_SANDBOX-.}/slave.jar -noReconnect -secret 4026fda6995da3083527505a05d92cadcb5e00eb0b477f0ff357097fadd59ae7 -jnlpUrl http://jenkins.xxx.net/computer/mesos-jenkins-09a5fb6724b44ed4bf10339c6aae4f1d-mesos-jenkins-do/slave-agent.jnlp'"
But in fact (Shown by **COMMAND** via **docker ps** command, the command "/bin/bash --login -- /entrypoint.sh" in Entrypoint override):
"/bin/sh -c 'java -DHUDSON_HOME=jenkins -server -Xmx640m -Xms16m -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC -Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true -jar ${MESOS_SANDBOX-.}/slave.jar -noReconnect -secret 4026fda6995da3083527505a05d92cadcb5e00eb0b477f0ff357097fadd59ae7 -jnlpUrl http://jenkins.xxx.net/computer/mesos-jenkins-09a5fb6724b44ed4bf10339c6aae4f1d-mesos-jenkins-do/slave-agent.jnlp'"

issues.title: Exponential back-off
issues.body:
# Proposal

Implement exponential back-off in Jenkins Mesos Plugin [JMP]
# Expected behavior

| Time X (in seconds) | Plugin | Mesos Master |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 0 | Does Nothing | Mesos has resources requested |
| 1 | JMP requests for resources to build code | Mesos doesn't have requested resources to offer |
| 2 | Jenkins Mesos Plugin retries after **2** seconds | Mesos doesn't have requested resources to offer |
| 4 | Jenkins Mesos Plugin retries after **4** seconds | Mesos doesn't have requested resources to offer |
| 8 | Jenkins Mesos Plugin retries after **8** seconds | Mesos doesn't have requested resources to offer |
| 16 | Jenkins Mesos Plugin retries after **16** seconds | Mesos doesn't have requested resources to offer |
| 32 | Jenkins Mesos Plugin retries after **32** seconds | Mesos doesn't have requested resources to offer |
| ... | Jenkins Mesos Plugin retries after **...** seconds | Mesos doesn't have requested resources to offer |
| ... | Jenkins Mesos Plugin Stops requesting, display a disposable JQuery banner on Jenkins Master | N/A |

issues.title: Supporting custom mesos resources
issues.body: It would be grate if jenkins mesos plugin could support additional mesos resources e.g. gpu. It is very useful for continuous integration in the machine learning area.

issues.title: Docker slaves launched with invalid hostname when label contains underscores
issues.body:
Hi all,

It would appear that if the label string for a Docker slave contains an underscore (i.e. `j_node5`) , Mesos tries to launch the Docker image with `--hostname mesos-jenkins-(UUID)-j_node5`.

Docker then complains that this is an invalid hostname and fails to launch the Jenkins node.
(This continues forever, filling up Jenkins with slaves that don't exist in Mesos)

A simple fix would be to strip the hostname of characters that aren't allowed as hostnames here: https://github.com/jenkinsci/mesos-plugin/blob/70fe128ca0d0e3f5d5718dbd9e8953133096331e/src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/mesos/JenkinsScheduler.java#L708 (or so it appears).

Thanks!

Hey Mani. Sorry for the delay on getting back to this PR. I took a look at the fix, but I would first like to understand the bug. Why does the Jenkins Slave go to LOST? Also, why does Jenkins master/framework not remove the slave when it reached a terminal state? Is the Jenkins slave still running?

The crux seems to be that supervise() checks the state of mesos scheduler (requests and results) and the state of jenkins (activeSlaves) but that only the former is impacted by statusUpdate(). AFAICT, when a Jenkins slave is terminated "terminateJenkinsSlave()" on the JenkinsScheduler should be called. So I think the correct solution here is to call supervise() inside that method too. That way irrespective of which event happens first (status update or jenkins terminate) we should be covered.

Also, not yours, but we should really rename getNumberOfPendingSlaves() to getNumberofPendingTasks() to avoid confusion.

issues.title: How to terminate nodes gracefully
issues.body:
Is there a user action one can take on the node to release the resources immediately.  There is another discussion on this topic at user@mesos.apache.org

Saw this issue https://github.com/mesosphere/marathon/issues/712

response from spodila@netflix.com

I believe this depends on the executor being used. A kill request to mesos driver from the framework scheduler is delivered to the executor. The kill request by itself is not a guarantee that the task will be killed, until honored by the executor. So, it is possible that the executor can be written to achieve the "graceful" behavior you desire. The resources assigned to the task aren't reclaimed until the task is reported killed/terminated by the executor. It is possible, for example, to perform "clean up" or "checkpointing" as part of a task kill request. But, that can be tricky in terms of delaying the actual kill logistics, and therefore making the resources available. 

If your question regarding a specific executor you are already using?

In case you are referring to resource oversubscription feature recently introduced, those kills are determined by an entity local to the Mesos agent node. "Grace" would be majorly influenced by that entity and less by the executor.

On Tue, Sep 22, 2015 at 9:39 AM, Jerry Lam chilinglam@gmail.com wrote:
Hi mesos users,

anyone knows how to kill a task running in Mesos gracefully? Thanks!

Best Regards,

Jerry

issues.title: Support for Maintenance Primitives
issues.body:
I wanted to get a conversation started on supporting [Maintenance Primitives](http://mesos.apache.org/documentation/latest/maintenance/) in the Framework. They are discussed in this [Mesos blog post](https://mesosphere.com/blog/2015/10/07/mesos-inverse-offers/).

> ## Maintenance-ready frameworks
> 
> One important note before we continue: the interface for inverse offers was not added to the native C++ scheduler interface. Instead, a framework must use the V1 HTTP API to receive inverse offers.
> 
> For maintenance primitives, inverse offers play a key role in draining a machine of tasks prior to starting maintenance on a machine. Draining a machine means stopping all the tasks running on the machine prior to the maintenance event. Frameworks are responsible for draining machines when instructed by the Mesos master (if they don’t, the operator can still “hard drain” the machine by pulling the plug).
> 
> In the workflow provided by the maintenance primitives feature, a machine starts to drain resources as soon as it is scheduled for maintenance. (For more details on how schedules are constructed, see the maintenance documentation). All frameworks using resources on the draining machine receive inverse offers periodically, asking for the resources back.

I have yet to find an example of how to have your framework register/talk to/etc. master using the .so _and_ the HTTP API, so that's probably step one.

Just starting the conversation, so, GO!

issues.title: Mesos cluster locked up by jenkins-mesos
issues.body:
This PR is a follow-up on the discussion https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/jenkins-mesos/OXd-Ol13iOg

Mesos 0.22.1
Jenkins LTS 1.596.3
Jenkins mesos 0.8.0

**Issue**
A single Jenkins Masters "locking" 100% (in fact, all remaining available) of a mesos cluster resources but not being able to create slaves. When this occurs, we often see 2 jenkins mesos frameworks registered from the same evil Jenkins master (the old one locking the resources, the new one using 0%)

By manually restarting the evil Jenkins master (via <jenkins_url>/restart or via marathon if you use it), all resources are freed and the cluster is working again. No need to restart the whole Mesos cluster and all jenkins masters.

It seems to occurs at a point when almost all resources of the mesos cluster are in use for a certain duration, and the evil Jenkins master is "waiting" for a valid offer.
The mesos driver might crash, leaving a orphaned mesos framework not able to release mesos offers...

Btw, configuring mesos offer timeout option to 10min (for example) does not solve the issue.

This is an annoying issue, as not easy to detect, and destructive because we have to restart the incriminated Jenkins master.
I will try to add more information (logs, screenshots) when it happens again.

issues.title: Support new Mesos task status TASK_ERROR
issues.body:
Currently, the Jenkins scheduler does not handle mesos TASK_ERROR status.
See https://github.com/jenkinsci/mesos-plugin/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/mesos/JenkinsScheduler.java#L601

This is a new status introduced in Mesos 0.21, but not used in this version (https://mesos.apache.org/blog/mesos-0-21-0-released/)
Starting from Mesos 0.22, this status can be sent.

I am currently investigating an issue where Jenkins sends a mesos slave creation request twice with the same ID, resulting in the reception of a TASK_ERROR status.
As of now, it crashes the Jenkins scheduler because of https://github.com/jenkinsci/mesos-plugin/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/mesos/JenkinsScheduler.java#L619

commits.message: take into account new mesos status TASK_ERROR

issues.title: mesos is crashing jenkins
issues.body:
We have 19 static mesos slaves and a single master. It is working pretty well with our build server which has build queues up to about a hundred jobs which typically take 5-60 minutes to execute.

On our regression servers, we have build queues of up to 800 jobs of about 10 minutes duration. Eventually jenkins crashes. It does not crash if we disable mesos.

We observe:

hundreds of 'offline' jenkins slaves are created - up to 700 - most of which appear to terminate without ever executing a job.

19 mesos slaves connected and executing tasks

Other, less critical issues include:
- huge logs (I turned them down using a setting in logging.properties) - but they still report INFO: items - I think Vinod is addressing that. Without the logging.properties filter, we have gigabytes of "INFO: Offer not sufficient for slave request:" messages.
- spam in config-history/config as an entry is created for each offline mesos slave created (up around the 10000 mark of spurious changes logged - I harvest them using a simple script, but it's a nuisance)
- spam in logs/slave/mesos-jenkins\* - 10s of thousands of entries for these 'offline' mesos instances - again, I can clean this up in our weekly janitor job
- number of executors per slave is set to 1 but it is not observed - it was most often running 2 tasks per slave - our tasks are too big to do that. Therefore I set the CPU requirement to 1.1 as an alternative method to restrict this, 

I have tried 0.7.0 (fails completely with NPE) and 0.8.0-SNAPSHOT from a few days ago (nothing runs at all "WARNING: Not launching mesos-jenkins-cef7d675-99b7-4ed5-b8cf-d5da02d07e65 because the Mesos Jenkins scheduler is not running")

I have tried jenkins-1.599 with the same result.

There's nothing useful in the jenkins.log when it crashes - the last messages on one machine last night were as follows:

issues.title: Support Scheduler HA
issues.body: The Jenkins scheduler should persist its frameworkId so that it can reregister under the same frameworkId on failover and reconnect to its running tasks. Also need to set failover_timeout to a sufficient duration.

issues.title: Will Mesos plugin support slaves connected through SSH, not JNLP?
issues.body: In some reason I'm more comfortable connecting my Jenkins slaves through SSH, then I can do more customization like adding environment variables inside the docker images. By far I know this plugin can only use JNLP connection, so is there a plan to add SSH?

issues.title: Plugin doesn't pull latest image when run jenkins slave in docker.
issues.body:
I specified docker image and try to launch jenkins in docker container. But it will always use local images rather than pull updates from registry. 

Any other workarounds? From example, run commands from container to host machines to update images so that next time updated image will be used.

issues.title: Set container hostname
issues.body:
I have successfully got the mesos plugin working with our mesos cluster, and it is able to create build slaves just fine. However I am trying to test some Saltstack states which require a hostname to be set for the tests to complete, adding `hostname` and `foobar01` into the parameters of the slave causes docker on mesos to bail out with -

```
exit status = exited with status 1 stderr = docker: Conflicting options: -h and the network mode (--net). See 'docker run --help'
```

I've also tried adding a `net` parameter to the slave with a `bridge` value, however the plugin seems to have `--net host` hard coded with no override.
`--net host --net=bridge` appears in the docker run command.

Also with the hostname, I'd like to be able to use information from the job... for example hostname of `foobar-${BUILD_NUMBER}`or `${BUILD_TAG}` opposed to the hostname of the mesos slave (which breaks the state testing).

Is this already possible, and if so how? If not, is it something that could be added?

issues.title: Slave username appears to be ignored
issues.body:
Hello,

I'm trying to set up this plugin.

I've been able to get it to create a mesos framework, but when I schedule jobs, the tasks appear to fail with the following error message (from the slave logs):

```
failed to start: Failed to create container: Failed to chown: Failed to get user information for 'jenkins': Success
```

Nothing is written to the `stdout` or `stderr` files, I got that log using `journalctl` on the slave.

This is despite the fact that I have set the Slave Username to a different user (root) in the cloud configuration.
What is this configuration supposed to do?  Can I customize what user mesos uses to create the container?

I am using mesos plugin version 0.6.0, jenkins 1.605 and mesos 0.21.0.

Here's a screenshot of our mesos plugin configs:

![](https://www.dropbox.com/s/lgdywhlk9r5rrnr/Screenshot%202015-03-25%2011.51.08.png?dl=1)

Thank you!

issues.title: Mesos slaves filling up /var/lib/jenkins/logs/slaves/
issues.body:
Looks like mesos slaves never delete their folder in:

/var/lib/jenkins/logs/slaves/

in the long run this causes issues because you eventually reach the max inodes per folder limit.

Is this expected?

issues.title: Launch dynamic slave image from Mesos-plugin
issues.body:
Today jenkins slave configuration are static. Container Image to launch is statically define into Jenkins configuration. 

It would be a nice feature to be able to put some "Jenkins Variable" compute from a master Jobs into the container image fields to be able to dynamically choose Container Image reference of a Mesos Jenkins slave. 

Today I need to launch a basic slave that launch the container that i want (Docker-in-Docker).

Hi Mohit,

We can assign different labels to Jenkins jobs(why should it be just 'mesos' and static?) so that they can be routed to the appropriate node(heavy jobs to powerful_node, light jobs to light_weight_node etc).I just implemented the part to have a list of labels configurable in mesos plugin with the slave configs(CPU, MEM etc) with label name as key so that mesos plugin can choose the matching offer and provision appropriate Jenkins slave based on the job's assigned label.
Mohit, I've updated the README with info and examples

Hi Vinod/Mohit,
Thanks for reviewing. Addressed all your comments, squashed my commits into a single commit.

I've fixed this issue in pull request https://github.com/jenkinsci/mesos-plugin/pull/28 .
Maven build(MavenModuleSet) assumes the slave root is absolute while it was just 'jenkins/' in Mesos provisioned Jenkins slaves. That's why the build was failing while trying to find maven31-agent.jar. I've made sure absolute path is returned for slave root. That fixes this issue.
Thanks Vinod for reviewing and merging the pull request.

Hi Vinod,

Thanks for reviewing. I'm not really sure why the slaves get into TASK_LOST state. I was running my cluster with Mesos 18.0.0. For testing the cluster I was running about 50 Jenkins instances and one build on each. Out of them 4 or 5 Jenkins slaves get into TASK_LOST every time. When the slave gets into this TASK_LOST state, it is removed only from the results map.: https://github.com/jenkinsci/mesos-plugin/blob/master/src/main/java/org/jenkinsci/plugins/mesos/JenkinsScheduler.java#L372 
When supervise() is called, it still counts the slave as active and it doesn't disconnect from cluster(When on demand reg is enabled).
The slave will actually be removed from Jenkins later by Jenkins housekeeping I believe which won't trigger any Mesos event. So there is no way framework would actually disconnect from the cluster.

That is why I've included this fix which works for me.

Thanks,
Mani
I agree. I've made the changes. Also renamed getNumberOfPendingSlaves() to getNumberofPendingTasks()

commits.message:
Add option to specify disk resource.

This option could be customized at slave level and hence
plugin would only accept resources that has the specified
amount in MB as Disk resource available. The option is
ignored for Docker containerizer and if the value is set
to 0.

This opens up up the killing of mesos slave if the slave
uses more that alloted amount of disk space by setting
--isolation with disk/du and
--enforce-container-disk-quota

Introduce support for Mesos maintenance primitives

This commit introduces the feature for the frameworks registered by Jenkins to ignore
offers having an unavailability (maintenance primitive) set.

The offers are only ignored when the current time is between the start and end time (start + duration)
of the unavailability.

Issue: https://github.com/jenkinsci/mesos-plugin/issues/216
Fix thread leak and deadlock on terminating slaves

Add configurable network mode for docker containers

This commit adds the possibility to configure the network mode of the
containerized Jenkins slaves provisioned by Mesos.

For now it is possible to pick "Bridge" or "Host", since these are
the two supported modes by Mesos (version 0.21.x).

Additionally, in "Bridge" mode it is also possible to define port mappings.

Issue: JENKINS-26324
[JENKINS-26321] Booleans for isReadOnly (Volume), isExtract and isExecutable (URI) are not handled properly

review_comments.body:
The "checked" attribute is for the checkbox to show whether the saved value is true or false. Attribute "value" would not show the actual saved value for me.

This means when, lets say, "readOnly" was saved as "true" the GUI would show it as unchecked and therefore "false".

Consequently this also means, when someone saves it again, it would override the "true" value in the config with the "false" value (without actively changing the value, but changing something else in the config, like a Maven Installation or something...).

I hope this is somewhat understandable (if not I can also provide screenshots).

Hmm, yeah. This change was not really meant to be in there as well (sloppy job of me reviewing the changes). I think it is not really necessary for this feature to work. However, I have to test this and clean up my pull request a bit.
Oversight, does not need to be there...

@barkerd427 I'm not sure if I understand you correctly, but if I do then you suggest adding a port mapping configuration for the HOST network mode, just for the host port?! I don't know if this is allowed by Docker (will have to try this).

@barkerd427 True that. Realized this when I started a slave with the VNC port exposed and I had no clue to which host port I have to connect. In the meantime I've implemented a feature which shows the (host) ports exposed on the Mesos Slaves on the Jenkins Slave Status page. Still, I have to test this and prepare another pull request...

@barkerd427 AFAIK now is that HOST mode in Docker exposes the ports of all services in a container on the host network interface. This means that it will not be possible to map ports differently (the ports would have to be configured in the service configuration, for example "Listen 80" in httpd.conf)

Mesos.

Set _JAVA_OPTIONS to use the executor memory as max heap

Recent JVMs determine automatically the max heap by taking about 1/4
of the available memory.

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/vm/gctuning/parallel.html#default_heap_size

The problem is that it takes as reference the host memory through
RLIMIT_AS flag value, and not the value defined by the cgroup it belongs
to.

As a consequence, if -Xmx is not explicitely specified and set to
relevant value, build processes may get killed by OOM-killer.

This takes the executor memory and set it as maximum heap size for any
forked jvm process which is what the user wants in most cases.

Wrap JenkinsScheduler run body in a try/catch/finally.

If any RuntimeException is raised during Scheduler execution, the object
was left in a corrupt state with running == true and driver != null.

The previous implementation would let any RuntimeException kill the
thread without any trace of it. Now, it is properly logged when it
happens and leave the scheduler in a correct state.

review_comments.body: There could be more than one slave info configured in Mesos plugin configuration. Remote FS Root can wary between slave info. Here I am making sure that I am fetching appropriate Remote FS Root value by picking up the right slave info.
In this case, Workspace is present in shared device like NFS Mount which is available for both Master and Slave.
Could you please provide more info on this ?

By default mesos plugin configuration, workspace will be created in mesos slave. In this case this feature won't work and will not throw any exception. For this feature to work we need to modify mesos pluign configuration to make use of NFS mount which is shared device between master and slave.

AFAIK, to get the workspace from the remote machine, you need to have jenkins slave process running on remote machine. I could see few challenges. We don't know the mesos slave used to run the latest build etc.. Actually this feature request is for those who have the workspace on the shared device like NFS Mount. Let me know your thoughts.

I had similar issue when developing this, there are some gotchas you should check:
- Jenkins slave will download slave.jar and a Java JNLP file from master to make handshake. The current Jenkins mesos plugin doesn't handle login when credential is required, you have to make anonymous user to be able to download the slave.jar and JNLP.. (@vinodkone Pls correct me if I'm wrong on this. )
- Jenkins has a security configuration to set a fixed or dynamic JNLP port range, make sure these ports are accessible by Mesos slaves.   
- Take a look Mesos LOG (master interface left sidebar link) when tasks keep spawning, it might be Mesos master is trying to make a response/connection to the Jenkins Mesos framework. Most likely one of the port is not opened.
- Make sure Jenkins plugin Mesos Offer attribute is configured correctly for your cluster. To trace if Mesos made a successful offer, you can take a look Jenkins server log if resources is offered to Jenkins.

In summary, take a look both Mesos and Jenkins log when new slaves created on mesos are offline, they will help you to trace down the issue. Hope this helps.

Can you please add a WARN log stating an attempt to stop the driver when it was `null`.

This piece of code might cause issues, because of the way JVM works. For ex: Consider a scenario where you have duplicate JVM arguments, let's say -Xmx. The plugin code will set the value based on the slave params. But, the user can pass another -Xmx which in this case will be appended to this string. Now, both Oracle and IBM JVMs chooses the rightmost argument as the winner. This can be a problem, because now the slave can be configured to use more memory then the intended value. A quick solution that I can think right now is to keep the user substitutions towards the left, and mesos-plugin params towards right, so that we can handle the order of evaluation. But, again  this will vary from JVM to JVM.

I think the validation logic should check for the presence of -Xmx entry, and then it might throw an exception if user provided -Xmx, to make it more explicit. But, a lot of developers prefer the fail silently approach where if -Xmx is detected, ignore it from the jvmArgs that are passed, and LOG a message at WARN level.

Also, the validation logic should work for both UI and XML routes of providing configuration.

Looks like the build failure is because the 0.18.1 `.jar` isn't available from [maven central](http://search.maven.org/#search%7Cgav%7C1%7Cg%3A%22org.apache.mesos%22%20AND%20a%3A%22mesos%22).

Related to this change: https://github.com/jenkinsci/mesos-plugin/commit/e8a13672784d53086114218a805d16a048af100e
https://jenkins.ci.cloudbees.com/job/plugins/job/mesos-plugin/87/

Haven't had a chance to do a local build of 0.18.1, but looking at the [diff](https://github.com/apache/mesos/compare/0.18.0...0.18.1#diff-b79dba05977e4e8dc72b94790e647ff4), it seems like the plugin should explicitly set `extract` to `false` rather than rely on the silent "failure" ([returning false instead of an error](https://github.com/apache/mesos/blob/0.18.1/src/launcher/fetcher.cpp#L51)) when the filetype doesn't match the whitelist (aka why bother entering the [extract block](https://github.com/apache/mesos/blob/0.18.1/src/launcher/fetcher.cpp#L227) if we already know the file shouldn't be extracted?).

Side note: It looks like Mesos will never enter the executable block because the string compare is now off by one.  The token will be of the form `http://localhost:8080/jnlpJars/slave.jar+1X` and [the string comparison is for 2 chars vs 1](https://github.com/apache/mesos/blob/0.18.1/src/launcher/fetcher.cpp#L194) .

pull_requests.title: Replace invalid hostname characters for task names and docker hostname
pull_requests.body:
Before this change, if you used the mesos plugin option 'Docker Image Can Be Customized'
and the resulting task name was less than 64 characters it could happen that the docker
image name contained invalid characters both for the task name and the docker hostname.
For example a custom label:foo/bar:latest would fail as a task name because / is invalid
in a task name since it breaks the directory structure. It would also fail as a docker
hostname since it needs to comply with RFC 1123 hostnames

Original commit was to fix https://github.com/jenkinsci/mesos-plugin/issues/251

Regarding why after JOB_LOADED milestone.
The cloud setup in hudon is really different from plugin setups. That was also the reason why the earlier milestones of PLUGIN_\* could not be used. The persisted member fields are not deserialized into the cloud class in those milestones
http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/org.jvnet.hudson.main/hudson-core/1.355/hudson/model/Hudson.java#2074

This is where with job_loaded milestone it reads up the config.xml where the fields related to the cloud class are persisted and also builds the slaves list

http://grepcode.com/file/repo1.maven.org/maven2/org.jvnet.hudson.main/hudson-core/1.355/hudson/model/Hudson.java#2104
Some labeling is done after job_loaded milestone for the slaves

I did see a null pointer exception when i changed to before=JOB_LOADED

So, just kept the init code after JOB_LOADED.
Squashed changes into a single commit.

Tom, are you testing against the latest plugin built from source. We addressed the issue that those pending tasks/jenkins slaves dont get launched and get terminated. Termination is handled through the RetentionStrategy as Vinod mentioned but we address the issue that we clear the task queue so that those dont get scheduled unnecessarily.
Refer
https://github.com/jenkinsci/mesos-plugin/pull/9

I will let Vinod review it  and comment but I would be hesitant to rely on features that is not officially released and force folks to update to 0.19 mesos version. Maybe a separate branch can be maintained?

The cpu flexibility is obvious. We also noticed for concurrent job requests, jenkins master is mostly using 1 executor (2 would cause waste of cpu resource). When there is a big pending queue at that point I have seen multiple executors being assigned to slave. Since we dont have a single master such big queue would be exception. framework name should be flexible, idle termination minutes developers have strong opinion. In our setup, when marathon is launching jenkins master for individual developers/project we are passing a preconfigured "config.xml" , so the jenkins code uses that for automatically registering the cloud plugin and starting the scheduler and we will have some preset variations of config.xml for folks to choose from. And since there will be tons of jenkins schedulers running, some way to differentiate properly through framework name is needed as well. At that point I asked Ashish to make all fields editable :)
Though probably we can go light on getters but I think the setters would be required when jenkins maps values from config.xml back to the fields.
I guess the getters would be required as well for display purposes since mostly the default config.jelly values will be overridden.

The Vagrant setup was using this modified plugin which I used to demonstrate running Jenkins builds in Docker containers - https://github.com/ahunnargikar/vagrant-mesos/raw/master/mesos-plugin/mesos.hpi . You can place the mesos.hpi file in your Jenkins plugins folder or upload it via the Jenkins master UI to activate it.

Disclaimer: Keep in mind that Mesosphere will deprecate the Docker executor soon now that Mesos 0.19.0 and Diemos is out so this is a temporary measure. Thats why I didn't do a pull request. > Jenkins has a security configuration to set a fixed or dynamic JNLP port range, make sure these ports are accessible by Mesos slaves.

If you check the slave logs (from the task) – do you see any errors relating to port binding, or any logs at all? I've had issues with other frameworks binding to the container's IP instead of the host, meaning when the jenkins master tries to connect to the slave (ip:port) it's unable to connect since that's just a local network-interface for docker.

That may well not be your issue, but worth checking it out.
@activars I think you mean @vinodkone ? ;-)
@vinodkone I've not yet given it a good go, though i'm planning to mid next week.

So this fix is redundant? I think these kind of time-based solutions aren't the best way of solving this problem in general, on the framework side. The framework should return offers back to Mesos as soon as possible once any scheduling logic has taken place.

Though this is planned to be improved with the introduction of [optimistic offers](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MESOS-1607) in the mean time the [offer timeout](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MESOS-186) feature should also help the situation which is due in the next release.

Can we close this, then?

review_comments.body:
As noted by @mbdas this is not a released version of Mesos. To get this version (and one you can use with this pull request) do the following..
- Download mesos from source and checkout the `master` branch.
- Apply this review request [r17567](https://reviews.apache.org/r/17567/)).
- Compile mesos using the usual `./bootstrap && ./configure && make`
- Install the compiled jar into the local maven repository using `make maven-install`
I believe this version bump occurs in mesos version `0.1.16/17` so also needs to happen here.

Moved `refuseOffer` up to the caller so that this one only does the `isExistingTask` part of the functionality.

Here's one theory. On line `272`, you remove the request. However, there's no hashCode method and if anything changes inside it, then the default hashCode will change rendering it unremovable. Then when you loop through the requests again, it will get matched again and launched once more. I'm not too sure about that though, all I know is that this PR does fix the issue.

With this PR, you subvert the entire issue using the assumption that taskId is unique. On line 586, if you launch a task that is already in the list of `results`, then why should we launch it again? It will only become an orphan. On line `592`, we check the master list of tasks that are running or finished and should never run again. This prevents another class of orphaned mesos tasks.

It's possible to receive an offer to launch the same mesos task after it has already been launched. There's nothing preventing that from happening right now and it leads to orphans. We've seen tasks that have launched in mesos but never get killed and don't do anything because they launch after it has already been launched. These if statements guard from that race condition
